awd_titl_txt: Combining Large-area Electronics with High-performance Computation for Scalable Ambient Intelligence
awd_abstract_narration:
Intellectual merit. The objective of this research is to investigate how high-performance silicon integrated circuits can work synergistically with a technology known as large-area electronics to increase the scope of functionality that electronic systems can provide. The proliferation of integrated circuits into our environments means that electronics has the potential to acquire a large number of signals that can be of high importance to us. It also means that electronics must exist unobtrusively in this space. This raises the need for systems that are (1) capable of large-scale physical interfacing through many sensing channels and (2) able to power themselves through embedded energy-harvesting devices, all in a compliant form factor. Large-area electronics is based on low-temperature processing of thin films. This enables diverse materials to be integrated to form a broad range of transducers. It also enables the use of plastic substrates, which can be conformal and physically large. Although transistors are also possible, these have orders of magnitude lower performance and energy efficiency than high-performance silicon integrated circuits. To enable extensive physical interfaces while also retaining high-performance signal-acquisition and computation capabilities, the two technologies must be combined. Such an approach, however, poses substantial scalability challenges. This study investigates methodologies and architectures that leverage devices from both technology domains to achieve highly-scalable and efficient means of exchanging data and power signals across the technology boundaries. 
   
Broader impacts. Electronics has demonstrated tremendous value in a wide range of applications. This research lays the ground work for electronics to interface with physical systems on a very large scale. This could lead to transformational systems for applications such as high-resolution sensing skins for monitoring structural health, interactive surfaces for visual computing, etc. In addition to important societal implications, such applications, due to their scale, could become a key driver for the electronics industry. This research develops specific design methodologies that will enable directed technical efforts in conjunction with the increased application scope, helping to focus industry efforts. This research will engage a new generation of engineers, particularly from underrepresented groups, by developing systematic principles for system design, from devices to applications. Both in outreach activities and in university education, the new forms possible for electronic systems will serve to illustrate the diverse applications that engineering has the potential to impact.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this project was to explore principles for creating hybrid systems, which combine a technology known as Large-Area Electronics (LAE) with silicon-CMOS electronics. LAE is based on low-temperature processing (<200C) of thin-films, which makes it compatible with a broad range of materials and substrates, thereby enabling the creation of diverse transducers (sensors and energy harvesters) integrated in a large and flexible form factor. But, the creation of systems requires realizing other functions as well (e.g., instrumentation of sensors, computation of data, power conversion and management of energy, etc.); while LAE enables the formation of thin-film transistors (TFTs) for realizing such functions, low-temperature processing leads to very low transistor performance. This motivates hybrid systems, combining LAE with conventional silicon integrated circuits (ICs).

The challenge with hybrid systems is the interfaces now required between the technologies. From experiences building several hybrid systems, this project investigated key architectural blocks required to address the interfaces, and the circuit topologies as well as device optimizations to efficiently realize these. The specific blocks identified included the following: (1) frequency modulators for enabling signal and power transfer between technology domains without metallurgical bonds, through inductive and capacitive interfaces; (2) low noise amplifiers for mitigating the sensitivity of sensor signals to coupling noise on long interconnects; and (3) scanning circuits for time multiplexing data from many sensors to a single interface.  

 For modulating data/power to a higher frequency, this project explored the use of inductor-capacitor (LC) TFT oscillators. A key insight derived was that such oscillators are particularly amenable for LAE implementation, because their performance depends strongly on the inductors, which can be made large to yield higher quality factors (by employing thicker traces and more turns) and thereby reduce the emphasis on the low-performance TFTs. In particular, the inductors resonant with the TFT capacitances, enable oscillation frequencies not limited by the low unity-current-gain frequency of the TFTs. Rather, oscillation frequency is fundamentally limited by the unity-power-gain frequency. Maximization of the unity-power-gain frequency motivated optimization of the TFT gate resistance, a parameter typically overlooked. In this way, the highest frequency oscillators every demonstrated for low-temperature-processed TFTs was achieved. From this, systems for wireless power transfer and 3D capacitance sensing were demonstrated.

 For low-noise amplification, detailed characterization was performed of the 1/f noise of the TFTs. It was found that low-temperature TFTs suffer from high 1/f noise due to high density of carrier traps in the semiconductor and semiconductor-dielectric interface. Typically, 1/f noise can be addressed by increasing the device dimensions. However, low-temperature-deposited gate dielectrics have increased probability of pinholes, elevating their failure rate with increased area. Thus, this project investigated a circuit-level solution known as chopper stabilization, where the input signal is first up-modulated to a frequency band less affected by 1/f noise, then amplified, and then down-modulated back to baseband. While this is effective, it requires operating the amplifier TFTs at an elevated frequency. Analysis was conducted to determine if this is viable and what its impact is on power efficiency. In fact, both viability and relative efficiency were validated, and the chopper-stabilized topology was demonstrated experimentally, achieving the lowest noise levels reported for low-temperature-processed TFT amplifiers. From this, a system for EEG acquisition and processing was demonstrated.

For time multiplexing, a scan-chain topology was designed, providing a baseline for the rate of sampling possible of large-area sensors. This established maximum array size constraints for LAE sensors, under Nyquist sampling. Such constraints became the motivation for algorithmic approaches focusing on increasing the array size of LAE sensors. Approaches include compressive sensing, embedded classification, and other signal processing methods. In particular, from this, a system for multi-speaker voice acquisition and separation from an array of thin-film piezoelectric microphones was demonstrated.     

Overall, this project made significant progress in developing architectural design principles, trade-offs, theory, and specific circuit topologies for hybrid systems. Much of these results were demonstrated experimentally, and related ideas were transferred to the academic and industrial communities. Of course, significant further research remains to be done, and perhaps the greatest outcome of this project is that it has opened up and advanced new fields for further research, which are already being pursued by various internal and external groups.
